title: Neglected dog’s fur was so matted vets had to remove his eye
text:
Oscar the Bichon Frise was found with his fur severely matted (Picture: SWNS)

A neglected Bichon Frise dog was found with his fur so matted vets were forced to remove his eye.

Owner Jean Simpson, 61, had been given Oscar ‘unexpectedly’ by a family member and failed to care for him properly.

She called RSPCA to re-home the dog after becoming unwell, but inspector Alice Cooper was shocked to find the animal’s fur had matted over his head, face, legs and feet.

Poor Oscar’s skin was also covered in sores and he needed more than 17 teeth removing.

One eye was permanently damaged and had to be removed, while Oscar will need medication for the rest of his life to save his sight in his other eye.

He had not been taken to the vets in three years (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

It took vets hours to shave his fur (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

It would have taken around two years for his fur to get in such a state and vets believe the infection in his eyes was present for at least six months, York Magistrates’ Court heard.

Inspector Cooper said: ‘His ears were two huge clumps of infected matted fur with green, yellow and black tar-like gunge, spreading out of his ears and across the side of his face.

‘One eye was completely matted over with fur and the other was crusty with green gunk stuck to the eyeball and surrounding area.

‘Oscar was making a whimpering noise and crying out in pain if I tried to stroke him or touch him to assess his condition.’

Vets had to sedate Oscar so that they could shave his coat, which took them hours – and he weighed a full kilogram less after the procedure.

Oscar was rescued by the RSPCA (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

Jean Simpson claimed she groomed Oscar herself (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

He had an infection in his ear (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

He was also found to be suffering from an ear infection and all of his health problems were described as ‘easily treatable’ had he been taken for treatment earlier.

Simpson was arrested and pleaded guilty to causing unnecessary suffering to an animal between January and June this year.

She had been Oscar’s sole carer for around three years and said she had groomed him herself.

He had not been to a vet since living with her, despite her being aware of his ear infection, as she said she could not afford it.

Simpson, of Malton, North Yorks, was sentenced to a 12-week custodial sentence, suspended for 12 months, and was also disqualified from keeping all animals indefinitely.

Oscar will need to take medication for the rest of his life (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

He has now been re-homed (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS)

She signed Oscar over into the RSPCA’s care and he was taken to York Animal Home, who have since re-homed him.

Inspector Cooper added: ‘Oscar has lost an eye and will need medication for the rest of his life but he’s been lucky enough to find a new home with a wonderful couple who absolutely adore him.

‘I appreciate that Ms Simpson didn’t plan on having a dog and that she couldn’t afford to treat him when he needed veterinary care.

‘However, anyone who is struggling to care for their animals needs to ask for help so animals are not left to suffer.’

description: A neglected Bichon Frise dog named Oscar was found with his fur so matted vets were forced to remove his eye.
